title: Common Catabolic Pathways
objectives: Understand the citric acid cycle (TCA) and its role in energy production
Describe the electron transport chain (ETC) and oxidative phosphorylation
Explain regulation mechanisms of both pathways
Identify clinical conditions related to these metabolic pathways

tca_cycle.title: Citric Acid Cycle (TCA)
tca_cycle.content:
Definition & Location

A cyclic mitochondrial pathway that oxidizes acetyl-CoA to CO2, producing:

  • 1 ATP/GTP (substrate-level phosphorylation)
  • 3 NADH + 1 FADH2 (10 ATP total)

Location: Mitochondrial matrix (absent in RBCs and sperm)

Key Reactions

  1. Citrate Formation: Acetyl-CoA + OAA → Citrate (irreversible, citrate synthase)
  2. Isocitrate Formation: Citrate ↔ Isocitrate (aconitase, inhibited by fluoroacetate)
  3. α-Ketoglutarate Formation: Isocitrate → α-KG + NADH + CO2 (rate-limiting, isocitrate DH)
  4. Succinyl-CoA Formation: α-KG → Succinyl-CoA + NADH + CO2 (α-KG DH complex)
  5. Succinate Formation: Succinyl-CoA → Succinate + GTP (substrate-level phosphorylation)
  6. Fumarate Formation: Succinate → Fumarate + FADH2 (succinate DH, inhibited by malonate)
  7. Malate Formation: Fumarate + H2O → Malate (fumarase)
  8. OAA Regeneration: Malate → OAA + NADH (malate DH)

Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Complex (PDHC)

Converts pyruvate → acetyl-CoA (irreversible):

  • Enzymes: E1 (pyruvate decarboxylase), E2 (dihydrolipoyl transacetylase), E3 (dihydrolipoyl DH)
  • Cofactors: TPP (B1), Lipoate, FAD (B2), CoA (B5), NAD (B3)

etc_oxphos.title: Electron Transport Chain (ETC) & OXPHOS
etc_oxphos.content:
Complexes & Electron Flow

  1. Complex I (NADH DH): NADH → Q (pumps 4H+), inhibited by rotenone
  2. Complex II (Succinate DH): FADH2 → Q (no H+ pumping)
  3. Complex III (Cyt bc1): QH2 → Cyt c (pumps 4H+), inhibited by antimycin A
  4. Complex IV (Cyt oxidase): Cyt c → O2 (pumps 2H+), inhibited by CN-, CO

ATP Synthase (Complex V)

  • Chemiosmotic Theory: Proton gradient drives ATP synthesis (3H+/ATP)
  • P/O Ratios: NADH = 2.5 ATP, FADH2 = 1.5 ATP
  • Inhibitors: Oligomycin (blocks H+ channel)
  • Uncouplers: DNP (dissipates H+ gradient)

regulation.title: Regulation
regulation.content:
PDHC Regulation

  • Allosteric: Activated by NAD+, CoA-SH; Inhibited by NADH, acetyl-CoA
  • Covalent: Kinase (inactive) vs Phosphatase (active) forms
  • Hormonal: Insulin ↑ PDHC synthesis

TCA Cycle Regulation

  • Key Points: Isocitrate DH (rate-limiting), α-KG DH
  • Activators: Ca2+, ADP
  • Inhibitors: ATP, NADH

OXPHOS Regulation

  • Respiratory Control: ADP availability drives ETC
  • Uncoupling Proteins: Thermogenin in brown fat

clinical.title: Clinical Notes
clinical.content:
PDHC/TCA Disorders

  • Lactic Acidosis: From thiamine deficiency (beriberi) or arsenic poisoning
  • Hyperammonemia: Depletes α-KG → ATP deficit
  • Fluoroacetate Poisoning: Blocks aconitase (pesticide)

ETC Disorders

  • MELAS Syndrome: Mitochondrial encephalopathy (Complex I/IV defects)
  • Leigh Disease: Infantile mitochondrial myopathy
  • Ischemia-Reperfusion: IF1 protein inhibits ATP hydrolase

Vitamin Deficiencies

  • B1 (Thiamine): PDHC dysfunction → Wernicke encephalopathy
  • B2 (Riboflavin): FAD deficiency → glossitis, angular stomatitis

faqs.title: FAQs
faqs.content:
Q: Why does TCA cycle stop under anaerobic conditions?

A: O2 is required as the final electron acceptor. Without it, NADH/FADH2 accumulate, inhibiting key enzymes like isocitrate DH.

Q: How does cyanide cause death so rapidly?

A: CN- binds irreversibly to cytochrome oxidase (Complex IV), halting all mitochondrial ATP production within minutes.

Q: Why are some tissues more vulnerable to ETC defects?

A: High-energy demand tissues (brain, heart, muscle) rely heavily on OXPHOS. Neurons can't switch to glycolysis like other cells.

Q: How does brown fat generate heat?

A: Thermogenin uncouples ETC from ATP synthesis, converting proton gradient energy directly to heat (important in newborns).
